newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jailed French cancer fund chief released on bail.
newsitem.headline: Jailed French cancer fund chief released on bail.

text.p: The former head of France's leading cancer research association was freed on bail on Friday after spending six months in detention for suspected fraud, justice sources said.
Jacques Crozemarie, 71, former president of the Association for Cancer Research (ARC) was released on bail of 500,000 francs ($100,000) pending possible trial.

He was forced to resign in January after a Court of Auditors found ARC spent little more than 27.2 percent of its funds, or 124 million francs ($24 million), on research aid in 1993 while its top officials lived in grand style.
Legal proceedings were then opened for suspected breaches of fraud laws in connection with ARC's finances.

ARC admitted it paid 13 million francs ($2.5 million) to an advertising agency that fed funds to Socialist politicians in the mid-1980s, when the party of the late president Francois Mitterrand was in power.
But ARC officials said there was no proof that the association had knowingly funded the party. The Socialists denied receiving cash from the association.
